author: djrtwo
content: Without a design in that direction, hobbyists will not have access to MEV markets. That said, without L1 support, designs are looking for "least bad" design rather than optimal

author: djrtwo
content: That said, I would argue that it never should have been `produceBlock` and that `produceBlockHeader` makes sense regardless

author: djrtwo
content: additionally, any design (even supported by L1) that has builder proposer separation requires signing of a header without of the contents known apriori

author: jgm
content: Given that the merge states that a block's execution payload must be valid, how would a validator client be able to verify this without the full block content?

author: jgm
content: (And this isn't the place, but I would say that I'm strongly opposed to "trusted relay" being considered the least bad solution, and don't buy the line that you have to have trusted relays for small players to be able to benefit from MEV.)

author: djrtwo
content: in PBS designs, a validator cannot apriori know the commitment that they are making, but (in a good design) the fault is attributable to the economic actor (relay) who created the fault. Thus all future proposers would reject execution payload proposals from that relay, going to other relays that have good reputaito or just dipping into local mempool

author: djrtwo
content: and note that any PoC on execution will almost certainly only be for attestations due to PBS designs

author: djrtwo
content: If you have anything that works in this market design, EF, flashbots, and others are incredibly open ears. The fundamental issue is with MEV theft and policing. This is an almost intractable problem with ~10 entities today in PoW whereas with hobbyists in the beacon chain, we easily get to 1000 entities

author: djrtwo
content: That said, I wish flashbots would disclose the problem statement -- MEV theft policing as being intractable -- a bit more clearly because without that context, designs like MEV-Boost are hard to evaluate

author: djrtwo
content: I just sanity checked -- https://ethresear.ch/t/mev-boost-merge-ready-flashbots-architecture/11177 does *not* provide the motivation on why the current market design does not scale and thus why even explore such solutions today

author: jgm
content: This assumes that there is significant choice in the market, which I'm not convinced about.  If we consider the trusted relay with two relays with 49% and 51% of the validator share, respectively, then it makes sense for all searchers to send their bundles to the 51% relay as that has a higher chance of having their bundle included earlier.  Given this, you would expect very strong network effects and a very small number of relays (1 plus a few odds and ends).

author: jgm
content:
I don't care about MEV theft.  It's a risk that should be dealt with by searchers on their own terms.  With a particular bundle they can send it to the earliest block proposer, or the most trustworthy (in their eyes), or anything inbetween.  The searcher can then deal with the outcome and act accordingly.  The protocol does not care whatsoever about the outcome, and nor should it.

As for the actors: I would far rather that actors had some protocol-level skin in the game.  There is literally no way of punishing relays outside of "don't send them future transactions",  which is very weak compared to punishments available for misbehaving validators.  And there's no way of knowing if a large relay is skimming off a few % of the transactions sent to it, due to the nature of MEV and there being multiple searchers.

I could go on with various other objections, but handing over a critical feature of the network a handful of (shady) organizations seems like complete madness to me.
